body: Are the commit dates right?!

I only intended to open the PR for the last two commits (both took place on 7/9/2019).  However, when I synced my fork from upstream and then committed my updates, it fell out this way (showing all of the previous commits for Java EE 8 support).  I initially closed the PR and I was going to try and do something different, but I reopened so that someone could advise.  There are only 12 file changes with this PR, but all of my previous commits are appearing in the list...will that cause an issue?  Thanks

Probably because I squashed and merged your previous PR I guess.  Will try same with this one and see where we get to.

It's a good idea to have your own master synced to upstream and create a temporary branch per PR.
Can you do a sanity check on the merge commit so we can revert if required before I sync with release branch tomorrow?  Thanks!
Thanks @neilcsmith-net I will take a look and let you know if I see any issues.  In the future, I will create a temporary branch per PR, as you recommend.  My apologies for not doing so this time.

> One thing that I have long wished for is a simple UI gesture to tell the IDE to throw out all its Java parser caches for a given source root and start over

I'd like to start working on this feature. Is resetting the parser cache a trivial method call somewhere, or is there more to it that I need to investigate?

(Things like "Find Usages" not working properly are driving me mad... I rely on it heavily when reviewing my own code. Currently, "Find Usages" (and "Go To Symbol", and presumably "Refactor Rename" etc.) will silently omit results at random, only to display them again if I go to the Java file in question, insert a space, and invoke Save to force CoS. Again, this is with the patch in this PR applied, on top of NetBeans 11.0.)
It seems this patch only affect literals? Shouldn't it fire for every kind of parameter? Maybe configurable for performance reasons? :)
I know that it is very late but this could even be merged in NB11.1.
Late as in past the deadline, sorry.  Build for vote has been made already.  Tag it with NB 11.2 if it's otherwise ready for merging when the merge window opens again and has been reviewed.

@neilcsmith-net it seems I cannot tag PRs as well as assign labels or set reviewers as I am not a committer.

I will ask on dev mailing list for someone to review after NB11.1 release, there is no reason to hurry.

Unless there is a new vc, I suggest we remember that 11.2 is not far away and that this is not an LTS, so the fact only JDK 8 is supported for this is not a blocker for 11.1. 

Also bear in mind that for Java EE, JDK 8 is a requirement, too, since servers such as GlassFish and Payara are tied to JDK 8 right now.

And -- we need to be very disciplined with our new time-based releases and identify problems like this during the betas, not during a vc.

There are also various issues around the Maven Frontend Application wizard (eg. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2439 and others) All could do with looking at during NB 11.2 window, and could consider pushing via AUC to NB 11.1 if feasible.

Yes, providing the various enhancements Toni is working on could be done via the update center, like Laszlo did for Gradle support during 11.0. Would that work, Toni? Trying to find a balance here between our various needs and wants. :-)
Now, when there is a chance for 11.1 VC2 due to NETBEANS-2824: Can you @neilcsmith-net consider including this fix as well, please?
@dukescript you're in luck! :smile: I'll merge for beta4.  Please make sure all is working correctly in it when ready before I roll vc2. Thanks!
Thanks!  A sanity check on beta4 sources when ready to make sure we've caught them all would be appreciated.

Unfortunately this PR is broken.  I've tried manually creating a patch based on your last commit and it also fails to build with the same error as in Travis

```
... netbeans/enterprise/j2ee.dd/build.xml:341: Replace: source file ...netbeans/enterprise/j2ee.dd/src/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/dd/impl/web/model_4_0_frag/WebFragment.java doesn't exist
```

It looks like the .gitignore file at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/enterprise/j2ee.dd/.gitignore needs updating for the newly generated files too.

I think you're going to have to reset your fork (or delete and create a new fork), keep master clean and in sync, apply these changes in a PR-specific branch, check it builds, and resubmit the PR.

Let me know if that's feasible today and I'll hold off beta4 build.  Thanks!
Neil, I will take a look into this issue.  Sorry for the troubles.  Thanks
It would be better to get this into 11.1 as then the steps described in [NETBEANS-2700](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2700) will be "followable".
It will be.  Should we also commit the sigtest files when they're generated into the release branch as well as master?

> Should we also commit the sigtest files when they're generated into the release branch as well as master?

We haven't done that previously as far as I remember, but possible and it makes sense.
@jlahoda @geertjanw considering we're doing another NB 11.1 beta and this looks a minimal but useful fix, shall we merge?
Good plan, I agree.
All green! Good to go, and thanks for sticking with it. :smile:
Thanks for everything Neil...it is appreciated!

The jenkins job was moved after graduation too:  https://builds.apache.org/job/netbeans-jsparser/

I put some work into it and while not finished, I think this is moving into the right direction:
https://github.com/matthiasblaesing/netbeans/tree/graaljs2

There are the updates in the tree:
- merge master into the branch to keep up with the recent changes
- fix compilation errors caused by changes in the graal.js API
- fix unittests in the webcommon cluster
- remove broken unittests in the webcommon cluster. They are not broken by the graaljs update, but by missing files, that were not donated

What reamains are mainly changed structures in the parser tree, these need further looking at.

@sdedic please consider pulling this in

The GraalJS parser's integration, in the state when I had to left it 
around NB 10 release, was rather unpleasant: there were a lot of cases 
when the (current) GraalJS parser misreported text positions - non-issue 
for runtime, but critical for editing features.

Are you sure all that is fixed ?

-S.

@sdedic no no everything is fixed. But I did not mean that it is ready, but that the changes improve the situation. I had to wade through compilation errors and non-graaljs caused unittest failures and if someone wants to pick up there he/she should not have to wade through the same mess.

I don't see this in master, but as an incremental update of this PR (still unfinished).
Ah, excellent, then: wouldn't it hep to change this PR's contents to a branch in NB repo, so you (others) can make PRs more easily against the work-in-progress code ?
Perfect job, @junichi11!

>     * remove broken unittests in the webcommon cluster. They are broken by missing files, that were not donated

Fixing the tests in the `master` is something that should be integrated first. Rather than deleting the tests, I'd prefer to fix them. Just take the files from http://hg.netbeans.org/releases - the fact that Oracle hadn't donated some files, doesn't mean they cannot be used - CDDL is an Apache friendly license.

In any case, if you can create a PR fixing the tests in master, that would be excellent.

@JaroslavTulach there is a slight missunderstanding: I improved the situation to the point where you can at least work with the code base and are not halted by false positives. I put some serious time into this - if you want it, take if not leave it, but I won't fix the mess others created again.
@BradWalker ware you still interested in this PR? I think @jlahoda reply needs to be adressed.

Thanks very much Matthias.. The only reason that I reordered the "deprecated" comment was to make it more "consistent" with industry practice. Usually the deprecated comments are the last thing.. But, if you prefer, in the future I can refrain from doing so.

Changed the order to the following:
- 100: MacOSX
- 200: NIO2
- 400: Windows
- 500: Linux

The upload of the new htmlparser binary succeeded and travis is happy.

@Chris2011 could you please have a look at the changeset. I get the feeling, that you might be interested in it anyway.
Had a look and it seems good to me. Thx for implementing it :). I saw your comment about the validator, so the HTML file will still underline all attributes that are not "correct"?
Yes, if you don't like these hints, open the options dialog, the editor category, hints tab and uncheck "HTML Validator -> Attributes".

I pushed my updated tree into the repository as the `graaljs2` branch. I experimented today a bit and it looks like graaljs will stay a moving target. Judging from signature check errors, methods were removed going from 19.0.0 to 19.1.0.
This will be fixed in a later git commit..

yeah thank you

Wow, all those "synchronized" things look terrific to me as well :-)
While we're at it, what about a cleanup and using a "Collections.synchronizedMap" instead? Wouldn't that be good enough?
@juneau001 Would you be kind enough to check that this PR won't cause any issues with your excellent work on Java EE 8 implementation?  Many thanks! :)

I have finally updated the code for this PR to add tests and also fix a side issue with the java hints to not complain about try, synchronized and switch blocks following if/else/for/while. However given the amount of time something seems to have bit rotted and I cannot update the PR with the new code.
@junichi11 Nice, thank you!
@junichi11 Could you please investigate the CI failure? Thank you.
@tmysik It failed because of timeout. I'm not sure about the cause. I'll try to restart the Travis CI build later or tomorrow. Thanks!
@junichi11 I see. OK, thanks!
Merged - thank you.
Merged - thank you.
Merged with minimal changes as: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/b283952dd6d62db912728bfef727d91f79d9050b

Switching to `Collections#synchronizedMap` would alter the semantics -- the synchronisation covers more than just the access to the map, but also the serialization of it (see `write`). So this is the minimal invasive change, but I agree, the class might need some love.
Merged - thank you.
Thank you, @matthiasblaesing  and @paulward24

The unittest fails currently - it tries to load `nbres:/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/dd/impl/resources/jobXML_1_0.xsd`, which is not present. The file is referenced in `EnterpriseCatalog.java`, line 126. My google-foo was good and I found a source for `jobXML_1_0.xsd`.

https://github.com/WASdev/standards.jsr352.jbatch/blob/master/com.ibm.jbatch.container/src/main/resources/xsd/jobXML_1_0.xsd

That file can be directly included (ASL2 licenses). I would add a new comment after line 10, where the file was from and that the notice file:

https://github.com/WASdev/standards.jsr352.jbatch/blob/master/NOTICE.txt

did not contain information, that applies to the referenced file.
No one raised points against this, the change is pretty self contained and looks sane.  Will merge.

Hi @matthiasblaesing .  Many thanks for your feedback.

This PR is to replace my previous PR, https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1266, which was (at least partially) regressed.

In that PR, you asked my to remove the reference tojobXML_1_0.xsd from EnterpriseCatalog.java as the licensing wasn't clear for that file.

Please clarify if you want to me to add the file, or I can again remove the reference from EnterpriseCatalog.java, whichever you think best.
I haven't had an opportunity to review this pull request yet, but I will do so tonight...along with the included change from @matthiasblaesing ...Thanks for working on this issue!

If I remember correctly I was not aware of a correctly licensed variant of jobXML_1_0.xsd. That has changed and thus I would include this compatible file.

Diese Nachricht wurde von meinem Android-Mobiltelefon mit K-9 Mail gesendet.
@tzezula Any opinion on this? I'd like to introduce this one early in 11.2 so if it would cause problems we can detect/revert the change before the release process would really spin up for 11.2.

I should mention that we intentionally do not include content of https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-netbeans/tree/master/lib folder in this donation. This folder contain jar files built from intellij-community and kotlin project sources. Of course you can use them if you wish, but we can't **donate** them because they are parts of other JetBrains projects.

Of course it would be much better (in both legal and technical aspects) for these jars not to be stored in the repo directly. I can give some advices how to avoid it (but sorry, can't do it myself due to lack of time):

- _intellij-core.jar_ artifact could be directly taken from here: https://www.jetbrains.com/intellij-repository/releases
- for other artifacts, I recommend to look at https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-eclipse project, _kotlin-bundled-compiler_ folder. As I can see it download everything (including even intellij-core) needed via Gradle _getBundled_ task declared at the end of _build.gradle_. Probably for NetBeans plugin it could be done in the same manner
Please refer to #1269

I've added `jobXML_1_0.xsd` to `enterprise/j2ee.dd/src/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/dd/impl/resources/`.  

I ran `ant -Dcluster.config=enterprise rat` locally, and it seems to recognize `jobXML_1_0.xsd` as Apache Licensed, so I haven't added it to the `licenseinfo.xml` file

Hope that is the right thing to do....
The Travis CI build passed :) Merging.
+1 i wait to try this fix
Yes, completed if I don't overlook anything.
I have reviewed the code and built successfully.  Everything looks good.  Thanks for making the requested updates for jobXML_1_0.xsd.

thanks @junichi11. I had some obscure token expired travis and was not able to see that. Now it seems accessible.

What is the good way, changing javac version ? or make the old vintage try catch finaly block ?
Let's update it :) e.g. `javac.source=1.8` (because NB needs at least Java8, maybe)
@junichi11 Should not we regenerate PHP sigfiles for PHP 7.4?
Thanks @juneau001 !  Appreciate your input :)

```
bwalker@brads-T460s:~/netbeans$ find ./ -type f -name "*java" -exec egrep -l " Class clazz =" {} \; | xargs sed -i 's/ Class clazz =/ Class<?> clazz =/g'
bwalker@brads-T460s:~/netbeans$
```

This should only pick up the variables that use a Class raw type. And not methods that might be doing the same thing. So no signature changes needed..

Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/f1603f06ea1033bec08e90c2a45585d8e1412c6f

Thank you.

@tmysik Yes, we should do it :) I'm going to do it in early September because documentation may be updated. (NetBeans 11.2 will be released in October[1] and PHP 7.4 will be released in November[2].) 
I'll create an issue for that.

[1] https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Release+Schedule
[2] https://wiki.php.net/todo/php74
Created: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2893

Today's changes above are just a rebase on top of master, removing the commit that represented the now-merged https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1273 . Changes that deal with the remaining TODOs will be added as separate commits later.
Really nice solution! +1
@junichi11 Perfect, I hope that the sigfile generator will still work :)

I'm now moving Batik libraries out of the "platform" cluster and into the "ide" cluster. I'm also moving the o.apache.commons.io and o.apache.commons.logging modules back into "ide".

When I now run my NetBeans Platform app, I get the following error message:

```
Warning - could not install some modules:
  org.netbeans.libs.batik - The module named org.apache.commons.logging was needed and not found.
  org.openide.util.ui.svg - The module org.netbeans.libs.batik would also need to be installed.
```

Presumably this is because my Maven-based platform app does not include the "ide" cluster (which would have included org.apache.commons.logging). I tried to include a direct dependency on the org.apache.commons.logging module from my platform app's pom.xml, like this:

```
<dependency>
  <groupId>org.netbeans.external</groupId>
  <artifactId>org-apache-commons-logging</artifactId>
  <version>${netbeans.version}</version>
  <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>
```

However, I still get the same error message ("The module named org.apache.commons.logging was needed and not found."). Does anyone know how I might fix this?
Fix looks sane - the case of names with trailing number was already fixed, but for other cases it might still be worth it.

The org.netbeans.libs.batik module will be part of the netbeans codebase, so that one I'm compiling with ant as part of the entire NetBeans build. But my NetBeans Platform application is built with nbm-maven-plugin. I just want to make sure that the new modules added in this PR plays well both within the IDE and from Platform applications.

The org.netbeans.libs.batik module has the following manifest:

```
Manifest-Version: 1.0
OpenIDE-Module: org.netbeans.libs.batik
OpenIDE-Module-Implementation-Version: 1
OpenIDE-Module-Localizing-Bundle: org/netbeans/libs/batik/Bundle.properties
AutoUpdate-Show-In-Client: false
```

and the following is its project.xml:

```
<project xmlns="http://www.netbeans.org/ns/project/1">
    <type>org.netbeans.modules.apisupport.project</type>
    <configuration>
        <data xmlns="http://www.netbeans.org/ns/nb-module-project/2">
            <code-name-base>org.netbeans.libs.batik</code-name-base>
            <module-dependencies>
                <dependency>
                    <code-name-base>org.apache.commons.io</code-name-base>
                    <run-dependency/>
                </dependency>
                <dependency>
                    <code-name-base>org.apache.commons.logging</code-name-base>
                    <run-dependency/>
                </dependency>
            </module-dependencies>
            <public-packages>
                <package>org.apache.batik.anim.dom</package>
                <package>org.apache.batik.bridge</package>
                <package>org.apache.batik.constants</package>
                <!-- ... More packages go here ... -->
            </public-packages>
            <class-path-extension>
                <runtime-relative-path>ext/batik-svg-dom-1.11.jar</runtime-relative-path>
                <binary-origin>external/batik-svg-dom-1.11.jar</binary-origin>
            </class-path-extension>
            <!-- ... Lots more batik-XXX-1.11.jars go here ... -->
            <class-path-extension>
                <runtime-relative-path>ext/xmlgraphics-commons-2.3.jar</runtime-relative-path>
                <binary-origin>external/xmlgraphics-commons-2.3.jar</binary-origin>
            </class-path-extension>
            <class-path-extension>
                <runtime-relative-path>ext/xml-apis-ext-1.3.04.jar</runtime-relative-path>
                <binary-origin>external/xml-apis-ext-1.3.04.jar</binary-origin>
            </class-path-extension>
        </data>
    </configuration>
</project>
```

How you generate the batik module mavenized ?


I would suggest to populate complely using nb-maven-plugin using a forced version on your own
after ant, ant build-javadoc,ant build-source-zips ant build-nbms

mvn org.apache.netbeans.utilities:nb-repository-plugin:1.5-SNAPSHOT:download -DnexusIndexDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/repoindex -Dmaven.repo.local=${env.WORKSPACE}/.repository -DrepositoryUrl=https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2
mvn org.apache.netbeans.utilities:nb-repository-plugin:1.5-SNAPSHOT:populate -DnexusIndexDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/repoindex -DnetbeansNbmDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/netbeanssources/nbbuild/nbms -DnetbeansInstallDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/netbeanssources/nbbuild/netbeans -DnetbeansSourcesDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/netbeanssources/nbbuild/build/source-zips -DnetbeansJavadocDirectory=${env.WORKSPACE}/netbeanssources/nbbuild/build/javadoc  -Dmaven.repo.local=${env.WORKSPACE}/.repository -DparentGAV=org.apache.netbeans:netbeans-parent:1 -DforcedVersion=11.1-TEST -DskipInstall=true -DdeployUrl=file://${env.WORKSPACE}/testrepo/.m2

Yes, that's what I'm doing ("ant build-nbms", and then using nb-repository-plugin to populate my local Maven repo with a forced version). Then I build my Platform app with the custom-built version of the platform.

OK, I found out how to avoid the error. The behavior is still a bit puzzling, because the org.apache.commons.logging module seems to behave differently than other runtime dependencies.

My platform app's dependencies work like this:

```
Application module (packaging=nbm-application), depends on:
* platform cluster
* My application's Branding module
* My application's "Kit" module

My application's "Kit" module (packaging=nbm), depends on:
* Main application dependencies.
* org-netbeans-core-output2 (runtime dependency)
* org-netbeans-modules-notifications (runtime dependency)
* JDBC drivers (runtime dependency)
* ...various other runtime dependencies...
* org-openide-util-ui-svg (runtime dependency)
* org-apache-commons-logging (runtime dependency)
```

Turns out, if I move the org-apache-commons-logging dependency to the "Application" module instead of the "Kit" module, the error goes away...

@neilcsmith-net I'm now revisiting the IconLoader approach. For this approach, the following modules would be required:

- Utilities API module (contains ImageUtilities, defines IconLoader API, must load the latter's implementation eagerly)
- SVGLoader API module (must be separate to allow lazy loading)
- IconLoader implementation module (depends on Utilities API and SVGLoader API modules, loads the latter's implementation lazily)
- SVGLoader implementation module (compile-time/non-lazy dependency on Batik Library)
- Batik Library module

In contrast, the previous approach taken in this PR required the following:
- Utilities API module (contains ImageUtilities, defines SVGLoader API, loads the latter's implementation lazily)
- SVGLoader implementation module (compile-time/non-lazy dependency on Batik Library)
- Batik Library module

Do you think the added complexity (2 extra modules) justifies adding the IconLoader API at this point?

(Note that in both of these approaches, the SVGLoader and Batik Library modules are optional.)
Great and many thanks.

Thanks for the review, I'll add them asap.

Sorry for the trailing spaces, this comes from the settings we use at office... Is there a NB settings that we can apply on the IDE to ensure that code matches standards ? (i.e. keep trailing spaces, don't organize imports, etc.)

Removing trailing spaces is a sensible decision. It requires however, that the projects are already clean, else you introduces changes all over the place, that you did not intent. Two things to prevent that:

1.) I assume you have "remove trailing space from" option activated in netbeans, I have that too, but I use "Modified lines only". That way, code you edited gets corrected, everything else is left untouched.
2.) Review commits prior to push

Sorry I don't think there is a silver bullet to tackle the whitespace problem easily.

@jmborer you raised https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1763 it would be great if you could have a look at this PR and test it.

Yes, with the growing number of cases where people mix various build technologies into the same directories, it is becoming more and more clear that the NetBeans system of one project type per directory doesn't fit many real world projects anymore.

My friend told me two months ago about his struggle with a project combining `package.json` and `build.gradle`. I wanted to help him with a "Multi Project" module. The idea was to create a decorator `Project` implementation that would delegate to all the other `Project` implementations that can physically recognize and handle the same directory. When user invokes build - it would invoke build via NPM and also via Gradle. The logical view would be merged. Queries like classpath would be delegated to both projects and their result merged as well.

Of course, this is not always what the user wants, so I was thinking of a UI that would allow the user to select the (set of) project(s) to delegate to. E.g. user could choose that only Gradle is preferred and the IDE should only invoke Gradle actions. Later, the user could switch to NPM view and work with the project only from the node.js perspective, completely ignoring Gradle.

Such "Multi Project" would implement "natures" in a reasonably natural way. "natures" - e.g. the current `Project` implementations would completely care about their physical representation on disk and physical commands to execute. The "Multi Project" would be just the UI to control & delegate to the "natures".

As far as I can tell @lkishalmi attempt is heading in the same direction. Just it starts with API change, I wanted to prototype the solution from outside. Solving the problem may turn into significant effort and having the ability to offer it as an extension module could help us get some user feedback before we change such a core functionality of the IDE. Ideally, once we succeed, all `Project` instances obtained from `ProjectManager` would be instances of the "multi project".

Btw. let's CC @jglick - he introduced the `ProjectManager` and fought hard against "natures".
Merged via: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/f0d26e4294bf2090a4a705a3317120504d932572

I am afraid I am not sure how exactly this patch should help? Projects are often through the FileOwnerQuery, which does not know currently which type of project it is trying to load.

When I was thinking of this, I was imagining two possible approaches:
1. a Multi Project similar to what @jtulach was proposing. Could work when the two projects merged into the Multi Project are sufficiently different (like possibly Java Gradle and NPM). Unlikely to work for two Java projects, but that is presumably fine. Maybe we would have a Multi Project that would allow only such combinations of projects that are known to work. This could be prototyped as an extension module.
2. have an action that would tell the project infra to recognize the given directory as a project of a particular type, and ignore all rest. Probably not reasonably doable as an extension module, but possibly also simpler to do.

I think that the code here might be to some degree useful for either of these, but details on what is needed will likely be more clear only when the actual UI so this is implemented.
